 ETD 		NCI Emergency Tier Designation NCI System

"The Emergency Tier Designation (ETD) is an electronic system to track and manage the NIH Emergency Tier Designation, a program that was developed to communicate to employees how they should respond in an emergency situation at NIH, based on their tier designation. It allows the tier-designated employees the ability to certify and acknowledge their tier designation.

"

 NED Portal/NED 		NIH Enterprise Directory NIH System

Most data from NED is stored in nVision and is available to be leveraged for reporting or other purposes. It's an HR registry for all employees.  

 eOPF 		Electronic Official Personnel Folder NIH System

"The eOPF is an electronic version of the paper OPF and a system for accessing the electronic folder online. The eOPF system combines document management with workflow capabilities. The eOPF allows each employee to have an electronic personnel folder instead of a paper folder. Benefits of eOPF include:

*   Immediate access to personnel forms and information for a geographically dispersed workforce.

* E-mail notification to employee when documents are added to their eOPF.

*   Multi-level secure environment with security rules for sensitive information.

*   No loss of official personnel documents due to filing and routing errors.

*   Reduced costs associated with storage, maintenance, and retrieval of records.

*   Electronic transfer of human resources (HR) data.

*   Integration with agency’s human resources information systems (HRIS).

*   Compliance with OPM and federally mandated HR employee record management regulations."

 DCEG Manuscript Clearance System 		NCI System

The Intramural system is intended to improve the efficiency of NCI Division by providing a platform to consistently manage the execution of business processes throughout an NCI Intramural Program. The Intramural system centrally collects and correlates fiscal and narrative project and study data in a manner that supports accurate and timely reporting and efficient strategic planning. The system allows program staff to reconcile Publications data and process NIH reporting tasks which inherently ASSIST with compilation of critical reports without direct interaction with the scientific faculty.

 None -- it supports nVision 		nVision User Registration NCI System

The nVision Automated Registration System allows users to view all nVision offerings along with permission details. Via this application, users can request access to data and unique privileges. The interface communicates with both approvers and registrants via email to streamline and automate the process. Approvers can approve or deny requests real-time. Built in tracking keeps a history of requests, approvals, justifications, and registration alterations (i.e. the adding or subtracting of elements). The application communicates with the user, updating them on registration Status and providing instructions on accessing key business areas and applications once registration requests are granted.

 NCI Mouse Repository 		NCI Mouse Repository NCI System The NCI Mouse Repository is an NCI-funded resource for mouse cancer models and associated strains. The repository makes strains available to all members of the scientific community (academic, non-profit, and commercial). NCI Mouse Repository strains are cryoarchived and distributed as frozen embryos. There is no charge for the embryos, however, the recipient is responsible for shipping charges. Users wanting to obtain embryos will out an online form. Researchers are encouraged to submit their cancer models to the NCI Mouse Repository for archiving and distribution. Additionally, the MicroRNAs (miRNA) Resource makes available 1501 genetically engineered mESC lines, harboring conditional microRNA transgenes.
 NFRP 		NCI Funded Research Portfolio NCI System The NFRP (NFRP) web site contains information about research grants, contract awards, and intramural research projects funded by the National Cancer Institute. The NFRP provides access to various NCI budget reports that contain information about research funding according to specific research categories

 HCIP 		Health Communication Internship Program, NCI Health Communications Internship Program Administrative Website NCI System

 ICRC 		NCI Introduction to Cancer Research Careers Program Administrative Website NCI System The Introduction to Cancer Research Careers (ICRC) application gives highly qualified undergraduate, post-baccalaureate, graduate, and recent graduate students who are financially disadvantaged and/or from underrepresented populations in science the opportunity to participate in vital cancer research at the National Cancer Institute (NCI). Selected candidates will have the opportunity to interview with top NCI Principal Investigators and potentially experience a summer or post-baccalaureate internship in an NCI research laboratory or office. Administrative features enable program managers to facilitate internal processes by maintaining site control data, managing users, submissions, Selection Committee Rankings, Interview requests and assignments of matched internship candidates.

 OLAW 		Office of Laboratory Animal Welfare Assurance NIH System

The Office of Laboratory Animal Welfare (OLAW) provides guidance and interpretation of the Public Health Service (PHS) Policy on Humane Care and Use of Laboratory Animals (Policy), supports educational programs, and monitors compliance with the Policy by Assured institutions and PHS funding components to ensure the humane care and use of animals in PHS-supported research, testing, and training, thereby contributing to the quality of PHS-supported activities

 FFR 		Federal Financial Report NIH System The FFR is used to submit financial information about individual grant awards. The FFR is required on an annual basis, except for domestic awards under the Streamlined Noncompeting Award Process (SNAP) and awards that require more frequent reporting. When required on an annual basis, the report must be submitted for each budget period no later than 90 days after the end of the calendar quarter in which the budget period ends.

The RPPR is used by grantees to submit progress reports to NIH on their grant awards. This page provides an overview of the annual RPPR, the final RPPR and the interim RPPR and provides resources to help you understand how to submit a progress report.

 GSA SAM 		GSA System for Award Management

The System for Award Management (SAM) (https://www.sam.gov) is a government run site that serves as a central registration point for government contractors. Instead of repeatedly submitting the same company information with each bid, the government created procurement systems for companies to submit required information through one source.

 PMS 		Payment Management System

The PMS (PMS) is a tool to help grant recipients draw down funds and file the FFR (FFR) . Primary responsibilities include: Executing awards; Maintaining minimum federal cash on hand by requesting funds from the PMS only for immediate disbursement (3 business days) and reimbursement unless otherwise specified in your Notice of Award; Reporting cash disbursements to the PMS and Maintaining your accounting records.

 WiTS 		Workflow Information Tracking System NIH System

WiTS at NIH increases overall organizational transparency and accountability via accurate and timely reporting, and provides management officials with a tool to identify, monitor and manage staff workload and performance.

 xTRACT 		Extramural Trainee Reporting and Career Tracking NIH System

xTRACT (xTRACT) is a module within eRA Commons used by applicants, grantees, and assistants to create research training tables for inclusion in progress reports and institutional training grant applications.

 

Because xTRACT is integrated with Commons it is able to pre-populate some training data for training tables and reports by using xTrain appointment and related data. This includes trainee names, selected characteristics, institutions, grant numbers, and subsequent NIH and other HHS awards. xTRACT also allows the manual entry of data, for information not found in Commons or xTrain. This manually entered information is stored in xTRACT and can be re-used when preparing subsequent training table submissions.

 DCIS 		Departmental Contracts (DCIS) HHS System

The Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) collects, tracks, reports, and transmits contract data using the Departmental Contracts Information System (DCIS). The DCIS program supports the acquisition related mission needs of the Department and ultimately assures compliance with various open government and transparency initiatives. The DCIS program is managed by the Office of Acquisition Business Systems within the Division of Acquisition, under the Office of Grants and Acquisition Policy and Accountability (OGAPA), which is within the Office of the Assistant Secretary for Financial Resources.

 CCR-SAM 		Central Contractor Registration System

CCR was migrated into the comprehensive SAM (SAM), which is part of an overall Integrated Acquisition Environment (IAE). IAE was initiated in 2001 to bring together different federal Procurement data systems into a unified system, with the intention of reducing duplication and information technology costs, and to help create a more streamlined and integrated federal acquisition process.

The information previously maintained in CCR, FedReg and ORCA now is contained within the Entity Management R15 in SAM. Legacy EPLS information resides in the Performance Information R15 of SAM.

You will need to create a new username and password to access the system, as your previous CCR, FedReg, ORCA and EPLS passwords will not work in SAM.

 NFRP 		NCI Funded Research Portfolio System Research Funding System

NFRP, a web Application designed to find NCI funded research Grant, Contract awards, and Intramural Research projects.

 

https://fundedresearch.cancer.gov/nciportfolio/ 

 

NFRP8 is managed by CSSI/KMSP and reports on NCI projects and NCI Research Coding. NFRP data are considered by the NCI as Official Public Data. Primary groups that supply data to NFRP are: RAEB (Extramural Grant and Research Contracts); DCEG (Intramural projects); CCR (Intramural projects); and, OBF (RMS and Leidos projects).

At the end of each FY, the Data Collection Process for NFRP is as follows:

 

  1. RAEB images final FY data and transfers it to an NFRP schema in I2E.
  2. KMSP accesses that data and runs scripts to load/copy it into the NFRP database.
  3. OBF collects data from Intramural groups and sends it via spreadsheets to KMSP.
  4. KMSP runs scripts to load the Intramural data to the NFRP database.
  5. OBF sends RMS and Leidos data to KMSP via spreadsheets.
  6. KMSP runs scripts to load the RMS and Leidos data to the NFRP database.

 

KMSP and OBF work closely during each new FY’s Data Validation Process. KMSP performs the R29 level QA-QC of NFRP data as it is being loaded to the NFRP database. OBF validates and approves project and disease category data before that data is made public on NFRP. The total NCI Budget is validated by OBF as the ‘Cancer’ category on NFRP. During the validation process, OBF staff have access to the NFRP development system where data are loaded as they are received. They can use the development system as an automated aid in their validation process. In addition, KMSP provides reports of the working FY data for OBF to validate.

 Stipend

A payment made to an individual under a fellowship or training Grant in accordance with pre-established levels to provide for the individual's living expenses during the period of training. A Stipend is not considered compensation for the services expected of an employee.

 OGCR 		Office of Government and Congressional Relations NCI DOC

The OGCR (OGCR), formerly the Office of Policy Analysis and Response (OPAR), was established in the early 1990's. Its initial responsibility was to advise the NCI Director, staff, and Council Council on legislative and Congressional activities as they relate to the NCI mission.

OGCR's duties have since expanded and today its functions cut across all levels of the NCI structure.

OGCR currently provides NCI and its constituents with three essential services:

  • Coordinate, monitor, and analyze congressional activities
  • Review, process, and respond to all requests for information from NCI that fall under the jurisdiction of the Freedom of Information (FOIA) and Privacy Act
  • Serve as NCI's liaison for all U.S. Government Accountability Office (GAO) and DHHS Office of Inspector General investigations

Today, OGCR facilitates the relationships between NCI, the Congress, and the general public.

OGCR aims to ensure that the NCI community is kept abreast of the congressional issues and interests that affect the Institute, and in turn NIH. OGCR also works closely with other offices both at the Institute and agency level.

Since NCI is a federally funded institute within NIH and ultimately DHHS, we are part of the executive branch of government. As such, we are non-partisan and do not lobby or endorse members of Congress or legislation.

 

https://www.cancer.gov/about-NCI/organization/OGCR

 Coding

Coding, as defined in this document, includes four distinct processes. The R29 and third of these processes are primarily associated with extramural awards, while the second and fourth apply both to intramural projects and extramural awards.

 

  • Initial Coding upon the receipt of an Application, for the purpose of Referral to the proper Division/PO and to assist in the review process. Other codes (e.g., CAA Class Codes (PCC), which include CA and PO codes) are also applied at this stage.
  • Cross-organizational Research Coding of extramural and intramural awards. This includes the CSO, SITE, and SIC codes. RAEB applies scientific codes to extramural awards, while intramural PI apply scientific codes to their own projects.
  • Division-level Coding of extramural awards, using codes defined by a particular NCI organization, but not used across the Institute.
  • Congressionally mandated, NIH-wide automated (with the exception of a few categories) Coding for RCDC (RCDC), which categorizes all NIH research projects.

 

Each of these Coding processes is carried out through distinct systems. Initial Coding occurs through the I2E Referral and PDA modules. Cross-organizational Research Coding occurs through FLARE (for extramural), through ARS (for CCR intramural), and through the DCEG Intramural System (for DCEG intramural). Division- level Coding uses the Program Coding Module or specific other systems (e.g., PMA for DCCPS). NIH-wide categorization occurs through the (mostly) automated RCDC process/system.

For more information on RCDC Coding process, see: https://RePORT.NIH.gov/RCDC/process.aspx

 MeDRA 		Medical Dictionary for Regulatory Activities In the late 1990s, the International Council for Harmonisation of Technical Requirements for Pharmaceuticals for Human Use (ICH) developed MedDRA, a rich and highly specific standardised medical terminology to facilitate sharing of regulatory information internationally for medical products used by humans. ICH’s powerful tool, MedDRA is available to all for use in the registration, documentation and safety Monitoring of medical products both before and after a product has been authorised for sale. Products covered by the scope of MedDRA include pharmaceuticals, biologics, vaccines and drug-device combination products. Today, its growing use worldwide by regulatory authorities, pharmaceutical companies, clinical research organisations and health care professionals allows better global protection of patient health.

 Research Coding 		Scientific Coding

Research Coding refers to the categorization of research projects according to scientific focus. In this process, research projects are analyzed and classified according to scientific topic and content. Research Coding allows the development of science-based Budget information, which can be used in portfolio analysis to examine the distribution of funds across research areas. Research Coding is also necessary to answer inquiries about the scientific and budgetary aspects of Institute-funded research.

 Peer Review 		42 CFR Part 52h, Scientific Review

A system for evaluating research Application utilizing reviewers who are the professional peers of the PI of the proposed project.

 

The core values of Peer Review drive the NIH to seek the highest level of ethical standards, and form the foundation for the laws, regulations, and policies that govern the NIH Peer Review process. The NIH dual Peer Review system is mandated by statute in accordance with section 492 of the PHS Act and federal regulations governing "Scientific Peer Review of Research Grant Application and Research and Development Contract Projects". NIH policy is intended to promote a process whereby Grant Application submitted to the NIH are evaluated on the basis of a process that strives to be fair, equitable, timely, and free of bias.

 

The R29 level of review is carried out by a SRG (SRG) composed primarily of non-federal scientists who have expertise in relevant scientific disciplines and current research areas.

 

The second level of review is performed by Institute and Center (IC) National Council Council or Council. Council are composed of both scientific and public representatives chosen for their expertise, interest, or activity in matters related to health and disease.

 

Only Application that are recommended for approval by both the SRG and the Council Council may be recommended for funding. Final funding decisions are made by the IC Directors.

 SO 		Signing Official Role An SO has institutional authority to legally bind the institution in Grant-administration matters by providing signature approval on Application submissions. The SO monitors Grant related activities within the extramural organization and may have a number of titles.
 RCDC 		Research, Condition, and Disease Categorization

In January 2009, the NIH added the RCDC (RCDC) reports to the RePORT SITE. RCDC is a computerized process the NIH uses to categorize and RePORT the amount it funded in each of 233 reported categories of disease, condition, or research R15.

 

RCDC provides consistent and transparent information to the public about NIH-funded research, providing a complete list of all NIH-funded projects related to each category. By clicking on each of the categories, the public can access full project listings for that category and view, print, or download the detailed RePORT.

 

Some of the funding amounts that RCDC reports might differ from NIH reports issued prior to FY2008. The reason for the difference is that RCDC is sorting funded research using a different method from the past. The way the NIH budgets and spends tax dollars throughout the year remains the same.

 

The NIH does not expressly Budget by category. The annual estimates reflect amounts that change as a result of science, actual research projects funded, and the NIH Budget. The research categories are not mutually exclusive. Individual research projects can be included in multiple categories SO amounts depicted within each column of this table do not add up to 100 percent of NIH-funded research.

 

https://RePORT.NIH.gov/RCDC/ 

 SIC 		Special Interest Category, Special Interest Categories

Reporting categories for NCI research projects that describe the major areas of study or scientific disciplines that are of stated or growing interest to decision makers at the National Institutes of Health, the HHS, Congress, or the public. SICs are added annually as the interests in different scientific disciplines change or grow.

Examples of SICs are Nanotechnology and Drug Development. A project is often coded by SIC and SITE.

 

https://fundedresearch.cancer.gov/nciportfolio/faq.jsp 

 Foreign Component

Under a Grant to a domestic institution, the performance of any significant scientific element or segment of a project outside of the United States, either by the Recipient or by a researcher employed by a foreign organization, whether or not Grant funds are expended. Activities meeting this definition include, but are not limited to:

  1. the involvement of human subjects or animals;
  2. extensive foreign travel by Recipient project staff for the purpose of data collection, surveying, sampling, and similar activities, or;
  3. any activity of the Recipient having an impact on U.S. foreign policy through involvement in the affairs or environment of a foreign country. Foreign travel for consultation is not considered a Foreign Component.

 Grant Number

Examples:

Grant Number: 1 R01 CA 123456-01A1

FAIN: R01 CA 123456

 

Application Type Activity Code NIH Admin Organization Serial Number Support Year Suffix Code
1 R01 CA 100228 01 A1 or S1

 

 

  • Application Type: Indicates whether the Application is new, a renewal (competing continuation), noncompeting, or other type. The example shows a new (Type 1) Application.

  • Activity Code: Lists the type of Grant that has been applied for; an (R01) is a traditional research project.

  • Administering Organization: A two letter abbreviation for the primary IC assigned. CA is the two digit code for NCI. The serial number is a unique five or six digit number that identifies the specific Application and indicates that it is the 100,228th Application assigned to the NCI.

  • Support Year: Indicates the current year of support. For example, the 01 shows that this is a new Grant. Sometimes the support year is followed by a suffix.

  • Suffix Code: Starts with an “A” to indicate an amendment to the Application. An A1 is the rst revised or amended Application. An “S” suffix code is used to show supplements. For example, an S1 is for the R29 supplement.

 Paylist 		System Research Funding System I2E

Paylist is an I2E Application module that allows selection of Grant to be paid, Coding of Grant for POR and Basic or Applied science and allows CAA staff to indicate which competing Grant Application should be paid.

CAA tool used to document paying Grant in rank order up to the payline.

 

Paylist is a module that allows NCI Extramural CAA staff to view the Paylist that is created via the Paylist Manager module and select the Application either for pay or skip. The CAA staff will provide the requested NCI dollar amount to support the Application that are selected for pay, which in accordance to the NCI Policy will be electronically routed to the CAA, Division, Funds, and Grant Management approvals. It also supports Coding of selected Grant within a Paylist.

 

Core Business Functions:

  • Supports electronic workflow that allows the NCI Extramural CAA staff to complete the selection of competing Grant in a Paylist for pay and/or skip. The saved Paylist will be electronically routed to the CAA, Division, Funds, and Grant Management approvals.
  • Provides the ability to assign Grant listed in a Paylist to a different Paylist.
  • Coding Paylists or Individual Grant Coding: Allows Coding of individual Grant in a Paylist (OR) en masse Coding of paylists for POR (POR) and Basic or Applied science
  • Built-in search capabilities: Performs default search based on the logged-in user’s role
  • RePORT Generation: Generates PDF or Excel RePORT on the search results
  • Adds the Official paycode to the system.

 

Primary Users:

  • Save/Complete Paylist: CAA Directors and Other CAA staff
  • CAA Approval: Branch Chief, Acting Branch Chief, & Division Level Approvers
  • Division Approval: Division Director, Acting Division Director, and Division Paylist Approver Delegate
  • Funds Certifier (OEFIA)
  • Grant Management Approver (OGA)

 

Size of Customer Base:

  • NCI CAA Staff

  • CAA level Approver - Chief/Acting Chief- 65

 CSO 		Common Scientific Outline

The NCI CSO (CSO) is a classification system organized around seven broad areas of scientific interest in cancer research to lay the framework for better coordination among research organizations and funding agencies:

  • cancer biology;
  • cancer etiology;
  • cancer prevention;
  • cancer early detection,
  • diagnosis, and prognosis;
  • cancer treatment;
  • cancer control,
  • survivorship, and outcomes research; and
  • scientific model systems.

 

The NCI research portfolio is organized around the CSO categories.

 

The CSO (CSO) is a Coding system used by public and private organizations in the US, UK, and Canada to describe research projects. The development of the CSO provides a framework to improve coordination among research organizations, making it possible to compare the research portfolios of public, non-profit, and governmental research agencies.

 Carryover 		As indicated by the NoA (NoA), Carryover authority provides Recipient permission to carry over funds unobligated at the end of a Budget Period to the next Budget Period. For awards under the Streamlined Non-Competing Award Process (SNAP), funds are automatically carried over and are available for expenditure during the entire Project Period. However, under those awards, the Recipient will be required to indicate, as part of its non-competing continuation request, whether its estimated un-obligated balance (including prior year Carryover) is expected to be greater than 25 percent of the current year’s total Budget as well as provide a dollar estimate of the Unobligated Balance. The Recipient must provide an explanation and indicate plans for expenditure of those unobligated funds. Awards not included in the SNAP population, do not have automatic Carryover authority and must submit a written request to NCI in order to receive authorization to use those funds. Obligated, but unliquidated, funds are not considered Carryover.

 FFR 		Federal Financial Report

The FFR shows the status of awarded funds for the Competitive Segment as maintained in the official accounting records of the Recipient institution.

  • SNAP: The FFR is due no later than 90 days after the completion of the Project Period, excluding awards to Federal institutions
  • Non-SNAP: The annual FFR is due 90 days after the end of the calendar quarter in which the Budget Period ends. The final FFR is due no later than 120 days after the end of the Project Period. Recipient are required to submit FFR for continued funding of their Grant(s).FFR

 

Reports of expenditures are required as documentation of the financial status of Grant according to the official accounting records of the Recipient organization. NIH requires all financial expenditure reports to be submitted using the FFR system in the eRA Commons: http://eRA.NIH.gov.

  • Both cash transaction data and expenditure data are required to be submitted.
  • Cash transactions are reported on a quarterly basis and expenditure data is primarily reported on an annual basis.
  • Except for awards under SNAP and awards that require more frequent reporting, annual reports must be submitted for each Budget Period no later than 90 days after the end of the calendar quarter when the Budget Period ended.
  • If more frequent reporting is required, the frequency and due date will be specified on the NoA.

Other factors related to a specific Grant may add additional reporting requirements. These requirements will be specified in the NoA. Grant management staff review and monitor the submission of these requirements.

 

Upon Grant Close Out a final FFR (FFR) must be submitted: https://www.whitehouse.gov/sites/default/ les/omb/assets/Grant_forms/SF-425.pdf

 SNAP 		Streamlined Noncompeting Award Process

A simplified process for submission of information prior to the issuance of a non- competing Award. Funds are automatically carried over and are available for expenditure during the entire Project Period. All NIH Award notices identify whether the Grant is subject to or excluded from SNAP. Under SNAP, the GMO negotiates the Direct Costs for the entire Competitive Segment at the time of the competing Award or, in the case of modular awards, determines the applicable number of modules for each Budget Period within the Competitive Segment. This eliminates the need for annual Budget submissions and negotiations, if applicable, and reduces the information the NIH requires to review, approve, and monitor noncompeting awards. Recipient are required to submit only the RPPR. For awards under SNAP (other than awards to federal institutions), a FFR (FFR) is required only at the end of a Competitive Segment, rather than annually.

 Assignment 		Grant Assignment, Assignment Process

HOW Application ASSIGNMENTS ARE MADE

 

The DRR (DRR) in the CSR (CSR) assigns each Application to a review group with the expertise to evaluate the scientific and technical merit of the Application and to one or more Institutes/Centers (ICs) for funding consideration.

 

While many NIH policies give authority to the DRR to determine assignments, staff of the DRR consult with ICs, Peer Review Officers (SRO) and IRG (IRG) Chiefs and applicants to reach the most appropriate Assignment. How much of the Application is read in making an Assignment? The honest answer is as much of the Application as is needed to make the determination. Referral staff have access to the entire Application. In many cases, they concentrate on the Abstract and Specific Aims in making an Assignment, with attention also paid to the Research Strategy. Requests made by investigators and the Assignment of previous Application are also considered. Referral staff regularly discuss the Assignment of Application and how to handle unusual situations.

 

The Assignment of a Application involves a series of decisions:

 

  • An Institute or Center (IC) is identified for primary Assignment for funding consideration. This determination is based on the focus and mission of each of the twenty-four Institutes and Centers of NIH. Due to the increasingly multidisciplinary nature of scientific inquiry, the complex biological problems being addressed, and the use of many common research methodologies the ICs share many common interests. The interests of the ICs are described on the main NIH Web SITE. Assignments are limited to the ICs that participate in the specific FOA used for Application submission.
  • Application may also receive dual IC assignments. Dual assignments acknowledge the shared interests of ICs in a topic and make all appropriate ICs aware of the Application. The primary Assignment is reflected in the Assignment number (CA for the NCI, AG for the National Institute on Aging, etc.). When multiple dual assignments are made, a rank order (secondary, tertiary, etc.) is not established. Both the primary and dual ICs have access to the Application and Summary Statement and Council consideration is given by both the primary and dual ICs. However, a dual Assignment does not necessarily increase the chance of an Award. The frequency of a dual Assignment leading to a change to primary and Award is less than 2%.
  • Finally, the Application is assigned for review to the CSR or to one of the other IC review groups. CSR reviews most R01s, fellowships, and Small Business Application. IC review groups handle Application that have institute-specific features such as CAA projects, training Grant, career development awards, and many responses to Requests for Application.

 

For Application assigned to an IC review branch for Peer Review, a general Assignment is made to that IC; the staff in the review unit subsequently decides whether the Application is to be reviewed by an IC standing committee or by an IC SEP.

 

For Application to be reviewed within CSR, a two-stage process is employed with initial Assignment to the IRG (IRG, a cluster of scientifically related study sections) level and subsequent Assignment to a specific SRG or SEP. By assigning all Application to the IRG level rather than directly to an individual SRG, the IRG Chief and the SRO within the IRG have the opportunity to gain a broad perspective of the areas of science covered by their IRG and to appreciate changes in emphasis and the emergence of new areas. A number of methods are used to determine assignments within the IRG, though all involve discussions among the SRO and the Chief. Finally, the IRG also have the option of suggesting that the Application is more appropriate for a different IRG; they may discuss this with other SRO or IRG Chiefs or return the Application to the DRR for reassignment.

 

Note: The terms SRG and SRG (SRG) are normally used for continuing review groups in CSR and the ICs, respectively. These are groups with members who have been appointed for multi-year terms of service; at any given meeting there are also usually temporary members present to provide any additional expertise needed. Special Emphasis Panels (SEPs) are review groups formed on an ad hoc basis to review Application requiring special expertise or when a conflict of interest situation occurs.

 

The following Information about the Assignment (review and IC) is accessed through the eRA Commons:

 

  • The Assignment number which is in the format 1 R01 CA987654-01 and provides the following information:
    • The type
      • Type 1 = new Application
      • Type 2 = renewal Application
      • Type 3 = revision Application
    • The Activity Code (R01, F32, etc.)
    • The IC with primary Assignment (in this example CA stands for the NCI)
    • A unique identifier - "987654"
    • The year and any suffix (01 is year 1, A1 indicates the R29 resubmission, S is used for revision)
  • Any dual assignments are indicated by the additional two-letter code.
  • The review Assignment, including the name of the SRG/SEP and the name, address, and telephone number of the SRO. The SRO is now the primary point of contact for the investigator throughout the Peer Review process.
  • Information about the primary IC to which the Application is assigned.

 

If the above information is not available in Commons within two weeks of submission, you should promptly contact the DRR (301-435-0715 ; csrdrr@mail.NIH.gov).

 

If there are questions about the appropriateness of the Assignment, the investigator should contact the SRO for review Assignment questions or the DRR for IC Assignment questions. If a change in IC Assignment is requested, it is most efficient to e-mail the request to csrdrr@mail.NIH.gov. The DRR will notify the investigator if the change is not possible. When the review location, primary institute, or timetable for consideration (Council round) is changed for an Application, the information will be updated in Commons.

 

Once the Application has been assigned, responsibility for the Application transfers to the Peer Review process.

 SBIR 		Small Business Innovation Research, R43/R44, R43, R44

The SBIR (SBIR) CAA is a highly competitive CAA that encourages domestic small businesses to engage in Federal Research/Research and Development (R/R&D) that has the potential for commercialization. Through a competitive awards-based CAA, SBIR enables small businesses to explore their technological potential and provides the incentive to profit from its commercialization. By including qualified small businesses in the nation's R&D arena, high-tech innovation is stimulated and the United States gains entrepreneurial spirit as it meets its specific research and development needs.

 

https://www.SBIR.gov/about/about-SBIR 

 

 

Small Business Innovative Research (SBIR)

  • Intended to stimulate technological innovation in the private sector by supporting research or research and development (R/R&D) for for-profit institutions for ideas that have potential for commercialization
  • Assists the Small Business research community in commercializing innovative technologies
  • Three-phase structure:
    • I - Feasibility study to establish scientific/technical merit of the proposed R/R&D efforts (generally, 6 months; $150,000)
    • II - Full research or R&D efforts initiated in Phase I (generally 2 years; $1,000,000)
    • III- Commercialization stage (cannot use SBIR funds)
  • Eligibility limited to U.S. Small Business concerns
  • The primary employment of the Project Director/PI (PO/PI) must be with the Small Business concern.
  • Multiple PO/PI allowed.
  • All ICs  utilize except FIC
  • See parent FOA: PA-12-088
  • The primary employment of the Project Director/PI (PO/PI) must be with the Small Business concern.
  • Multiple PO/PI allowed.
  • All ICs  utilize except FIC
  • See parent FOA: PA-12-088

 

 https://Grant.NIH.gov/Grant/funding/SBIR.htm

 DRR 		Division of Receipt and Referral, NIH Division of Receipt and Referral, NIH CSR Division of Receipt and Referral, CSR Division of Receipt and Referral NIH DOC All Grant Application submitted to the NIH go to the DRR (DRR) within the CSR (CSR). After receiving the Application DRR:

 SPORE 		Specialized Program of Research Excellence

This FOA (FOA) invites Application for P50 Research Center Grant for SPORE (SPORE). The CAA will fund P50 SPORE Grant to support state-of-the-ART investigator-initiated translational research that will contribute to improved prevention, early detection, diagnosis, and treatment of an organ-specific cancer or a related group of cancers. For the purpose of this FOA, cancers derived from the same organ system (i.e., a group of organs that perform a common function) are considered related. Examples of such organ systems include gastrointestinal, endocrine and other biological systems. Other programmatically appropriate groups of cancers may include those centered around a common biological mechanism critical for promoting tumorigenesis and/or cancer progression in organ sites that belong to different organ systems. For example, a SPORE may focus on cancers caused by the same infectious agent or cancers sustained and promoted by dysregulation of a common signaling pathway. In addition, a SPORE may focus on cross-cutting themes such as pediatric cancers or cancer health disparities. The research supported through this CAA must be translational and must stem from research on human biology using cellular, molecular, structural, biochemical, and/or genetic experimental approaches. SPORE projects must have the goal of reaching a translational human endpoint within the Project Period of the Grant.

 

https://Grant.NIH.gov/Grant/guide/PA-files/PAR-18-313.html

  • One of many types of cooperative agreements

 OA 		Office of Acquisitions, NCI Office of Acquisitions NCI DOC

The NCI OA awards and administers contracts and simplified acquisitions in support of the institute’s mission to prevent, diagnose and treat cancer. During the course of the acquisition process, the OA will ensure that customer service is paramount, communications are open and continuous, positive relationships are fostered, sound business judgment is employed, and acquisition strategies are creative and proactive. In SO doing, the resulting Contract awards will wholly and completely meet CAA office needs, be compliant with Law and Regulation, and have a positive, long-lasting effect towards fulfilling the NCI’s mission to prevent, diagnose and treat cancer afflicting people worldwide.

The Frederick National Laboratory for Cancer Research (FNLCR) is supported by the Management and Operations Support Branch (MOSB) in the OA. If you are interested in learning more about the FNLCR, please visit the FNLCR Acquisition Portal.

 

https://ncioa.cancer.gov/OA-internet/

 Human Subject

A living individual about whom an investigator (whether professional or student) conducting research obtains data through intervention or interaction with the individual or obtains identifiable private information. Regulations governing the use of human subjects in research extend to use of human organs, tissues, and body fluids from identifiable individuals as human subjects and to graphic, written, or recorded information derived from such individuals. See the NIH Grant Policy Statement for more:

http:/Grant.NIH.gov/Grant/policy/nihgps/index.htm.

 RFAB 		Risk Factor Assessment Branch NCI DOC

The RFAB (RFAB) focuses on (1) the development, evaluation, and dissemination of high-quality risk factor metrics, methods, tools, technologies, and resources for use across the cancer research continuum, and (2) the assessment of cancer-related risk factors in the population.

RFAB's mission is to plan, develop, direct, coordinate, and evaluate a comprehensive CAA of research aimed at:

 

  1. Developing and validating tools for measuring the full complexity of a range of cancer-related risk factors across the lifespan, sociocultural subgroups, and socioecological contexts. Examples of risk factors include but are not limited to diet, physical activity, and weight management.
  2. Producing data on the distributions and determinants of cancer-related risk factors in the general population and among subgroups, to assist in formulating clinical and public policies that address these factors
  3. Synthesizing and disseminating findings from the research supported by RFAB to the public, health care professionals, scientists engaged in cancer control, and the public health community.

 

 https://epi.Grant.cancer.gov/RFAB/ 

 OMPC 		Office of Management Policy and Compliance, Office of Management Policies & Compliance NCI DOC

The OMPC (OMPC) is responsible for NCI-wide evaluation and implementation of NIH standards and oversight in the areas of Risk Management, Records Management and OMB clearance. OMPC advises NCI senior leadership on the execution and oversight of Federal, Departmental and NIH administrative management requirements and develops management and administrative policies, procedures and evaluations throughout the Institute. OMPC provides analytical business data and supporting recommendations through the delivery of organizational studies and management assessments and surveys to ensure streamline business processes that are compliant to the Federal requirements.

 

https://www.cancer.gov/about-NCI/organization/OMPC 

 ARA 		Awaiting Receipt of Application System Research Funding System I2E

ARA (ARA) is an Application that supports NCI approval process for CSR unsolicited Application (required mostly for those requesting high funding).

I2E Application

 

https://eRA.NIH.gov/NIH_and_grantor_agencies/other/awaiting_receipt_of_Application.cfm 

The main role of the Awaiting Receipt of Application (ARA) module is to electronically track and link information received in advance of submission to a Application, after the Application is received or logged into the eRA system. For instance, an IC may be willing to accept a Application that is at or over the $500K limit of Direct Costs in any year. The IC uses an ARA form to electronically inform CSR's DRR (DRR) of this concurrence. DRR staff will then match the ARA request from the IC to the right Application and eRA will automatically inform the IC.

ARA also facilitates requests for assignments from ICs and other information that needs to be connected to a specific Application.

The new ARA replaces the manual paper-based process that has been used to match information to Application.

OGA responsibilities are complex and critical to the NCI's mission and success. We plan and direct all NCI business-related activities associated with the negotiation, Award, and ongoing management of NCI Grant and cooperative agreements to help financially support cancer research activities throughout the United States and around the world. OGA staff ensures that all legal, regulatory, and policy requirements are met by NCI and the Recipient.

 R23 		NIH Exploratory/Developmental Research Grant Award (R21), NIH Exploratory/Developmental Research Grant Award

  • Encourages new, exploratory and developmental research projects by providing support for the early stages of project development.  Sometimes used for pilot and feasibility studies.

  • Most ICs utilize
  • See parent FOA: PA-16-161

 Dual Review System 		Peer Review process used by NIH. The R29 level of review provides a judgment of scientific merit. The second level of review (usually conducted by an IC’s Council/Council) assesses the quality of the R29 review, sets CAA priorities, and makes funding recommendations.
 IACUC 		Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee Committee

A committee set up by an institution to review the institution’s CAA for humane care and use of animals. The IACUC reviews research protocols involving the care and use of animals at the institution and makes recommendations to the Institutional Official regarding any aspect of the institution’s animal CAA(s), procedures, facilities, or personnel training.

 

If working with research animals, a certification of IACUC approval is required every three years. Grant management staff review and monitor the submission of these certifications.

SPIRES (SPIRES) – Application that maps publications from the NLM PubMed database to the respective Grant. SPIRES data is used for portfolio analysis and CAA management by internal NIH communities. IMPAC II

 PA 		Program Announcement

A formal statement that describes and gives notice to the Recipient community of the existence of an NIH-wide or individual IC Extramural Research activity/interest
or announces the initiation of a new or modified activity/interest or mechanism of support and invites Application for Grant or Cooperative Agreement support. PA are published in the NIH Guide to Grant and Contracts: http://Grant.NIH.gov/Grant/guide/index.html. Funds may or may not be set aside for PA.

 

PA (PA or PAR)

  • Signals interest in important and/or understudied R15 of science to scientific community.

  • Generally involves multiple Application receipt dates.

  • Generally uses only standard review criteria.

  • Has no money committed up-front.

 

NIH currently has 27 active Parent CAA Announcements (PA). Six Categories of Parent PA:

  • Research (R) Announcements (R01; R03; R13; R15; R21; STTR; SBIR);
  • Research Training (T) Announcements (T32; T35); Career Development (K) Announcements (K01; K02; K08; K23; K24; K25;
  • K99/R00); Fellowship (F) Announcements (F30 [x 2]; F31; F31-Diversity; F32; F33);
  • Administrative Supplements Announcement (for all Activity Code; to promote diversity; to promote re-entry).
  • Post-Award Administrative Action Announcements (Type 6; Type 7)

 Contract

Contract (Research & Development [R&D]): An instrument used by the NCI to procure cancer research services and other resources needed by the Federal Government. Contracts are legally binding documents and used when the principal purpose of the transaction is to acquire a specific service or product for the direct benefit of or use by the NCI.

 

Contract (under a Grant): A written agreement between a Recipient and a third party to acquire routine goods or services.

 SRG 		Scientific Review Group, Study Section Committee

A SRG is a FACA-chartered committee or SEP; performs R29 level of review (CSR and NCI).

 

A Peer Review committee group of primarily non-government experts (peer reviewers), qualified by training or experience in particular scientific or technical fields, or as authorities knowledgeable in the various disciplines and fields related to the Application under review, to evaluate and give expert advice on the scientific and technical merit of the Application. No more than one-fourth of the members of any SRG may be Federal employees, as noted in 42 CFR 52(h).

 

The R29 level of a two-stage Peer Review system. These legislatively mandated panels of subject matter experts are established according to scientific discipline or medical specialty. Their primary function is the review and rating of research Grant Application for scientific and technical merit. They make recommendations for the appropriate level of support and duration of Award. They are a component part of an IRG (IRG) that advises on the scientific and technical merit of research Application. Also known as SRG.

 

Standing Study Sections

Review most investigator-initiated research Application (R01, R03, R21, R15, and Ks). Standing study sections are those with both permanent members and temporary members.

View Standing Study Sections 

 

SBIR/STTR Study Sections

Recurring special emphasis panels (SEPs) review SBIR (SBIR) and Technology Transfer Research Application (STTR). They include only temporary members.

View Small Business and Technology Transfer Study Sections 

 

Fellowship Study Sections

Recurring special emphasis panels (SEPs) review individual fellowship Grant Application - F30, F31, F32, F33. Temporary members are recruited based on expertise needed for each meeting.

View Fellowship Study Sections

 

All Other CSR Study Sections (SEP)

Other one-time or recurring Special Emphasis Panels (SEPs) are held to review Application on special topics and members conflict Application. They include only temporary members.

View Special Emphasis Study Sections 

 OCC 		Office of Cancer Centers NCI DOC

The OCC

supports a diverse, nationwide network of NCI-designated cancer centers performing basic laboratory, clinical, and population-based research in cancer. Through the P30 Cancer Center Support Grant (CCSG), the OCC funds research infrastructure in centers that meet rigorous standards for transdisciplinary, state-of-the-ART research programs focused on developing new and better approaches in cancer prevention, diagnosis, and treatment. Cancer centers earning the P30 CCSG Award also receive the NCI ‘designation’ which recognizes their achievement of these standards and enhances their ability to leverage additional resources for cancer research, education, and care.

 

https://cancercenters.cancer.gov 

 Application Type 		Grant Application Type
Type 1 New

Request for support of a project that has not yet been funded.

Type 2 Renewal (aka Competing Continuation)

Request for an additional period of support based on a previously funded project. Competing continuation Application compete with other competing continuation, competing supplemental, and new Application for funds.

Type 3 Competing Revision or Administrative Supplement Request for additional funds, either for the current operating year or for any future year previously recommended, to cover increased costs (noncompeting Administrative Supplement) or to expand the scope of work (Competing Revision).
Type 4 Extension Request for additional time and/or funds beyond those previously awarded. Typically limited to certain mechanisms, including Merit (R37), Developmental/Exploratory (R21/R33), and Fast-Track Small Business Grant SBIR/STTR (STTR/SBIR). These Grant do not compete for available funds.
Type 5 Noncompeting Continuation Request to pay next Budget increment of a current Award through RPPR (RPPR); does not compete for available funds.
Type 6 Successor-in- Interest and Name- Change Agreements Request to pay next Budget increment of a current Award through RPPR (RPPR); does not compete for available funds.
Type 7 Change of Recipient or Training Institution Request for support of a funded project to be transferred from one Recipient or training institution to another.
Type 8 Change of Institute or Center Change of NIH awarding IC for the Noncompeting continuation (Type 5)
Type 9 Change of Institute or Center Change of NIH awarding IC for a Renewal (Type 2)

 

 SEP 		Special Emphasis Panel Committee

Special Emphasis Panels (SEPs) are review groups formed on an ad hoc basis to review Application requiring special expertise or when a conflict of interest situation occurs. This in contrast to SRGs which are groups with members who have been appointed for multi-year terms of service, sometimes joined by temporary members with special expertise. A SEP is an ad hoc FACA committee; convened generally for one meeting (CSR and NCI).

 

Charter:

Review Grant and Cooperative Agreement Application and Contract proposals for research projects and for research and training activities in broad areas of basic and clinical cancer research. Members and Chairs, rather than formally appointed, are selected to serve for individual meetings on an "as needed" basis in response to specific Application or proposals.

 

Objective and Scope of Activities:

The SEP reviews Grant and Cooperative Agreement Application and Contract proposals for research projects and for research and training activities in the broad areas relevant to basic and clinical cancer research. The Panel evaluates proposals for support to make available to the research community, on a competitive basis, Contract resources for the preclinical development of drugs, biologics, clinical assays, and other developmental programs that would ultimately benefit the advancement of clinical studies. The Panel will provide input to NCI on scientific prioritization of National Clinical Trials Network (NCTN) concepts across diseases.

 

Description of Duties:

The SEP provides concept review of proposed Contract or Grant solicitations and reviews Grant and Cooperative Agreement Application and Contract proposals for research projects and for research and training activities in the broad areas of basic and clinical cancer sciences, clinical trials prioritization evaluation and applied research and development programs of special relevance to NCI. The preclinical and clinical discovery and development CAA Panels, managed by the DCTD (DCTD), also evaluates proposals for support to make available to the research community, on a competitive basis, Contract resources for the preclinical development of drugs, biologics, clinical assays, and other developmental programs that would ultimately benefit the advancement of clinical studies. Furthermore, the Panel will provide input to NCI on scientific prioritization of NCTN concepts across diseases guided by a set of criteria when there are insufficient resources to support trials for all NCTN Scientific Steering Committee approved concepts.

 

https://deainfo.NCI.NIH.gov/Council/SEP/SEP.htm

 eGrants 		System Research Funding System

eGrants is an Application designed to automate the storage and retrieval of documents contained in the official NCI Grant files.

eGrants contains the official electronic Grant file for NCI funded Grant. It is managed by the NCI OGA. Questions about eGrants should be directed to eGrants Issues.

The large majority of the data associated with NCI Application and awards are stored both in IMPAC II and in systems that are part of the I2E umbrella, with one exception. The OGA-operated eGrants system stores funded and unfunded Grant data.5 This system interchanges data with the Datamart and I2E extensions, but remains independent of the CBIIT umbrella.

 CTRP 		Clinical Trials Reporting Program, NCI's Clinical Trials Reporting Program

CTRP maintains a comprehensive database of information on all NCI-supported interventional clinical trials open to accrual as of January 1, 2009. This database, also referred to as CTRP, helps identify gaps and duplicate studies in clinical research, facilitates clinical trial prioritization, and standardizes trial data capture and sharing.

Key benefits of CTRP include:

  • Standardized abstraction of protocol information
  • Consistent terminology and Coding to optimize search and retrieval of cancer trials information
  • Biomarker and patient-level accrual data
  • Standardized person and organization data elements

 

https://www.cancer.gov/about-NCI/organization/CCCT/CTRP 

 Intramural Research

Research performed by NCI employees at the NIH is called Intramural Research. The NCI Intramural Research CAA (IRP) consists of the CCR (CCR) and the DCEG (DCEG), and is dedicated to a comprehensive understanding of cancer. IRP Government scientists, research fellows, and visiting scientists from around the world conduct basic, clinical, population-based, and prevention studies. They also collaborate with national and international investigators in academia and in the biotechnology and pharmaceutical industries to help expedite the Application of new knowledge for the development and delivery of products that will benefit human health.

 CRS 		NCI Center for Research Strategy, Center for Research Strategy NCI DOC

The CRS (CRS) is a science-based office that collaboratively develops recommendations for addressing scientific opportunities, monitors the direction and Application of the NCI’s scientific knowledge and resources, and identifies research funding gaps.

The CRS responsibilities are to:
  • Synthesize input from NCI leadership and external stakeholders to inform priority initiatives
  • Identify scientific opportunities within priority initiatives
  • Coordinate development of programs across the NCI to address opportunities
  • Conduct portfolio analysis to support priority setting and scientific strategic planning
  • Collect and analyze data to identify research accomplishments
  • Recommend strategies for allocating resources effectively

 

 https://www.cancer.gov/about-NCI/organization/CRS 

 

CRS manages the ICRP (ICRP) data system and its public-facing website located at https://www.icrpartnership.org. Currently RAEB provides data to ICRP, but plans have been made to have CSSI/KMSP provide NFRP data to ICRP.

 JIT 		Just-In-Time

Within the Status module of the eRA Commons, users will find a feature to submit JIT information when requested by the NIH. NIH policy allows the submission of certain elements of a competing Application to be deferred. Through this module, institutions can electronically submit the information that is requested after the review, but before Award. JIT includes, certification of IRB approval, proof of human subjects education training, certification of IACUC approval, Other Support for Key Personnel, etc.

 PFR 		Program Funding Request

CAA Funding Requests is an I2E Application for NCI Extramural CAA staff to create and submit initial pay (exception), supplement, skip requests that require approvals within NCI. It also supports the creation of RFA/PA funding plans that will be submitted for SPL approval. Application provides electronic workflow, enforcement of funding levels of authority policy, and automated approval for funding requests and plans.

 

I2E CAA tool used to document funding actions that fall outside of the normal process of paying Grant in rank order (Paylist).

 

PFR (PFR) is a module that allows the NCI Extramural CAA staff to create and submit CAA Funding Requests (Initial Pay, Supplement), Skip Requests and Funding Plans that is routed for electronic approvals based on the NCI Levels of Authority (LOA) policy.

Supports compliance with the NIH audit requirements by providing appropriate electronic approval documentation for awarding Grant Application.

 

Core Business Functions:

  • Allows the NCI Extramural CAA staff to create and submit Initial Pay, Supplement, Skip, and Funding Plan requests for automated approvals by the Scientific, Funds, and Grant Management officials.
  • Enforces compliance with the NCI funding policies by determining the Scientific Levels of Authority (LOA) for requests based on the following criteria:
    • Cost Center/Budget Mechanism of the Application
    • Request Type
    • Funding Source
    • CAA recommended dollar amount
    • IMPAC II Grant Status
    • Grant Priority Score and Percentile
    • Fundable Score Range and DOC exception selection parameters defined in the Paylist Manager system
  • Support RFA/PA Funding Plans:
    • Allows the CAA staff to create a standard Funding Plan for a single or combined RFA/PA spanning one or more applicable NCAB dates and provide funding details for each Application selected for funding.
    • Determines the Application that will be skipped and not considered for funding in a Funding Plan, by allowing the CAA staff select the Application for funding consideration and define the Fundable Score Range.
    • Facilitates SPL presentation process, by supporting the generation of the Funding Plan word document templates with pre-populated data that could be used by the CAA staff to create the Scientific Rationale and justification for skipped Application.
  • Provides the ability to upload justification and supporting documents needed for the approval of the request
  • Supports System Integration:
  • Compares the fundable Score range defined for the Cost Center/Budget Mechanism in the Paylist Manager system to the Application Score or percentile to determine the appropriate request types that can be selected for a specific Application.
    • Integrates with the Grant Portfolio Management and Tracking System (GPMATS) – Upon the completion of the PFR, the system automatically creates Action Requests in GPMATS for OGA to track Award/post Award actions
    • Supports the Pre-appl Concept for OEFIA: PFR Integrates with OEFIA’s FAM module to do one or more of the following: Display the active and projected CAN in the OEFIA Funds approval page, Set/Update the Official Pay Code, Assign CAN number based on the selection of pre-appl or roll-up option, Support TCS calculation, Record the funding source usage based on the request type.
  • Creates Funding Package of fully approved PFRs and Funding Plans for automated retrieval by OGA’s eGrants system
  • Allows the users to track the status of request.
  • Enables automated email notifications
  • Built-in search capabilities: Performs default search based on the logged-in user’s role
  • RePORT Generation: Generates PDF or Excel RePORT on the search results

 

Primary Users:

  • Create PFR: CAA Directors and Other CAA Staff
  • Submit PFR: Requesting CAA Directors (OR) CAA Directors associated with the same CAA as the Requesting PO
  • Scientific Approval (determined by the system):
    • CAA Directors
    • Division/Center Directors
    • NCI Director
    • Scientific CAA Leaders (SPL) Committee Designee
  • Funds Certifier: ARC Funds Approvers and OEFIA Financial Analysts
  • Grant Management Approval: OGA Chiefs

 

Size of Customer Base:

  • NCI CAA Staff
    • NCI CAA Directors – 300
    • Other CAA Staff – 130
  • Division/Center Directors (includes Acting/Deputy Division Directors) - 19
  • NCI Director or Designee - 1
  • Scientific CAA Leaders (SPL) Committee Designee - 1
  • ARC Funds Approvers - 13
  • OEFIA Financial Analysts - 8
  • Grant Management Approvers - 4

 

 

 

 Activity Code

A 3-character code used to identify a specific category of Extramural Research activity, applied to financial Assistance mechanisms. NIH uses three funding mechanisms for Extramural Research awards: Grant, cooperative agreements and contracts. Within each funding mechanism, NIH uses 3-character Activity Code (e.g., F32, K08, P01, R01, T32, etc.) to differentiate the wide variety of research-related programs NIH supports.

 

There are >240 Activity Code currently listed at https://Grant.NIH.gov/Grant/funding/ac_search_results.htm 

 

NCI Grant Award Activity Code can be found at: https://deainfo.NCI.NIH.gov/flash/awards.htm 

 PI 		Principal Investigator Role

The individual(s) designated by the Applicant organization to have the appropriate level of authority and responsibility to direct the project or CAA to be supported by the Award. The Applicant organization may designate multiple individuals as CAA directors/principal investigators (PO/PI) who share the authority and responsibility for leading and directing the project, intellectually and logistically. When multiple PO/PI are named, each is responsible and accountable to the Applicant organization, or as appropriate, to a collaborating organization for the proper conduct of the project or CAA including the submission of all required reports. The presence of more than one PO/PI on an Application or Award diminishes neither the responsibility nor the accountability of any individual PO/PI.

 DCEG Intramural System 		System Research Funding System

Used by DCEG to support business processes related to Intramural Research, including Research Coding.

DCEG provides information to NIDB via XML-formatted data from the DCEG Intramural System. Research Coding data are submitted via spreadsheets to OBF and OBF uses the data from those submissions to populate the NFRP.

 CSSI 		Center for Strategic and Scientific Initiatives, Center for Strategic & Scientific Initiatives, Center for Strategic Scientific Initiatives NCI DOC

 Key Personnel 		Role The PI (PI) and other individuals who contribute to the scientific development or execution of a project in a substantive, measurable way, whether or not they receive salaries or compensation under the Grant.  Modular Grants

Under modular Budget proposals, applicants are instructed to prepare the Budget request in direct-cost modules of $25,000 (not including third-party F&amp;A Costs) up to a maximum direct-cost level of $250,000. (Budget requests beyond this level follow traditional Application instructions.) This process eliminates the need for much Budget detail, thereby relieving administrative burdens on both NIH staff and Recipient organizations and simplifying cost management for NIH CAA staff.

 RFA 		Request for Application

An RFA is a formal statement that solicits Grant or Cooperative Agreement Application in a well-defined scientific R15 to accomplish specific CAA objectives. An RFA indicates the estimated amount of funds set aside for the competition, the estimated number of awards to be made, whether cost sharing is required, and the Application submission date(s). For cooperative agreements, the RFA will describe the responsibilities and obligations of NIH and awardees as well as joint responsibilities and obligations. Application submitted in response to an RFA are usually reviewed by a SRG (SRG) specially convened by the awarding component that issued the RFA.

 

Request for Application (RFA)

  • Used to stimulate research in a priority R15.
  • Usually involves a single Application receipt date.
  • Allows use of standard plus special review criteria.
  • Has money committed up-front (i.e., “set-aside”).

 

NCI participation on another IC’s RFA requires additional approvals

  • NCI participation on another IC’s RFA, when the set-aside commitment is $1M or less, requires:
    • Initiation by PO;
    • Approval by Division Director; and
    • Approval by the SPL and then by the Director.
  • NCI participation on another IC’s RFA, when the set-aside commitment will be >$1M, requires:
    • Initiation by PO;
    • Approval by Division Director; and
    • Approval by NCI SPL and, if >$2M, by BSA.

 

 New Investigator 		A PO/PI who has not previously competed successfully as a PO/PI for a substantial independent research Award is considered a New Investigator. For example, a PO/PI who has previously received a competing NIH R01 research Grant is no longer considered a New Investigator. However, a PO/PI who has received a Small Grant (R03) or an Exploratory/Developmental Research Grant Award (R21) retains his or her status as a New Investigator. A complete list of NIH Grant that do not disqualify a PO/PI from being considered a New Investigator can be found at http://Grant.NIH.gov/Grant/new_investigators/index.htm 
 Score 		Scoring, NIH Grant Score

The NIH utilizes a 9-point rating scale (1 = exceptional; 9 = poor) for all Application; the same scale is used for overall impact scores and for criterion scores (Score Guidance).

Before the SRG meeting, each reviewer assigned to an Application gives a separate Score for each of (at least) five review criteria (i.e., Significance, Investigator(s), Innovation, Approach, and Environment for research Grant and cooperative agreements; see Review Criteria at a Glance). For all Application the individual scores of the assigned reviewers and discussant(s) for these criteria are reported to the Applicant.

 

In addition, each reviewer assigned to an Application gives a preliminary overall impact Score for that Application. In many review meetings, the preliminary scores are used to determine which Application will be discussed in full at the meeting. For each Application that is discussed at the meeting, a final impact Score is given by each eligible committee member (without conflicts of interest) including the assigned reviewers. Each member's Score reflects his/her evaluation of the overall impact that the project is likely to have on the research field(s) involved.

 

The final overall impact Score for each discussed Application is determined by calculating the mean Score from all the eligible members' final impact scores, and multiplying the average by 10; the final overall impact Score is reported on the Summary Statement. Thus, the final overall impact scores range from 10 (high impact) through 90 (low impact). Numerical impact scores are not reported for Application that are not discussed (ND), which may be reported as ++ on the face page of the Summary Statement and typically rank in the bottom half of the Application.

 

Applicants just receiving their scores or Summary Statement should consult our Next Steps page for detailed guidance. Applicants seeking advice beyond that available online may want to contact the NIH PO listed at the top of the Summary Statement.

 

An Application may be designated NRFC (NRFC) by the SRG if it lacks significant and substantial merit; presents serious ethical problems in the protection of human subjects from research risks; or presents serious ethical problems in the use of vertebrate animals, biohazards, and/or select agents. Application designated as NRFC do not proceed to the second level of Peer Review (National Council Council/Council) because they cannot be funded.

 Transfer of Recipient Organization

Periodically NIH is asked by Recipient institutions to accommodate administrative changes for managing Grant. In these cases the PI, other researchers and the performance of the research is not changing; however, the administrative oversight and responsibilities for the Grant is shifting to a different legal entity. The transfer of a Grant requires Prior Approval by the Grant management and CAA staff assigned to the Grant.

 QVR 		Query, View, Report

QVR (QVR) - IMPAC II tool that lets NIH staff search, view and retrieve detailed information about Grant Application and awards.

 

 

  • Provides a series of preformatted reports for most business areas - Receipt and Referral, Peer Review, Grant Management, Scientific Programs, Budget, Training, Portfolio Analysis, and other areas.
  • Acts as a portal for viewing a variety of research and research training Application and awards from IMPAC II, including:
    • Current data (data since 2007)
    • Historical data (back to 1970)
    • FY-end (FY) frozen records (called Pub files) (starting in FY 2002)
    • NIH Annual Intramural Project reports (from the last closed FY and before)
    • Grant-related publications from PubMed, via SPIRES database
  • • Finds scientifically similar projects related to one or more targeted Grant or manually entered text (such as from a publication or PA) using the various LIKE functionalities in QVR, or querying the RCDC Categorization data.
  • Searches and downloads information on people involved with IMPACII Grant as investigators, Key Personnel, participants, or reviewers.
  • Searches and downloads data on sites and collaborators in foreign countries as tracked using the Foreign Application and Component Tracking System (FACTS)
  • Allows access to broader extramural obligation data from the NIH Data Warehouse for Grant, contracts, interagency agreements, taps, etc.

 STTR 		Small Business Technology Transfer, R41/R42, R41, R42

The STTR (STTR) is another CAA that expands funding opportunities in the federal innovation research and development (R&D) arena. Central to the CAA is expansion of the public/private sector partnership to include the joint venture opportunities for small businesses and nonprofit research institutions. The unique feature of the STTR CAA is the requirement for the Small Business to formally collaborate with a research institution in Phase I and Phase II. STTR's most important role is to bridge the gap between performance of basic science and commercialization of resulting innovations.

 

https://www.SBIR.gov/about/about-STTR 

 

 

 

STTR (STTR)

  • Intended to stimulate scientific and technological innovation through cooperative research/research and development (R/R&D) carried out between Small Business concerns (SBCs) and research institutions (RIs)
  • Fosters technology transfer between SBCs and RIs
  • Assists the Small Business and research communities in commercializing innovative technologies
  • Three-phase structure:
    • I - Feasibility study to establish scientific/technical merit of the proposed R/R&D efforts (generally, 1 year; $150,000)
    • II - Full R/R&D efforts initiated in Phase I (generally 2 years; $1,000,000)
    • III- Commercialization stage (cannot use STTR funds)
  • Eligibility limited to U.S. Small Business concerns
  • Project Director/PI (PO/PI) may be employed with the SBC or the participating non-profit research institution as long as he/she has a formal appointment with or commitment to the Applicant SBC.
  • Multiple PO/PI allowed
  • All ICs  utilize except FIC
  • See parent FOA: PA-12-089

 

https://Grant.NIH.gov/Grant/funding/SBIR.htm

 FOIA 		Freedom of Information Act

The basic function of the FOIA is to ensure informed citizens, vital to the functioning of a democratic society.

 

Since 1967, the FOIA (FOIA) has provided the public the right to request access to records from any federal agency. It is often described as the law that keeps citizens in the know about their government. Federal agencies are required to disclose any information requested under the FOIA unless it falls under one of nine exemptions which protect interests such as personal privacy, national security, and law enforcement.

 

https://www.FOIA.gov 

 NoA 		Notice of Award

The legally binding document:

 

  • notifies the Recipient of the Award of a Grant;

  • contains or references all terms and conditions for the Award; and

  • documents the obligation of Federal funds.

 

The Award notice is issued electronically and may be accessed through the eRA Commons: http://eRA.NIH.gov/Recipient/index.cfm.

 
 Grant Activity Type 		Grant Type Major Grant activity types
  • R Series: Research for a discrete, specific project (e.g., R01, R03, R21)
  • P Series: Multi-component efforts with common overall objective or theme (e.g., P01, P30, P50)
  • K Series: Career Development (e.g., K01, K08)
  • F & T Series: Fellowship and Training (e.g., F32, T32)
  • U Series: Cooperative Agreements - substantial programmatic participation by funding entity (e.g., U01, U24, U54)

 Financial Conflict of Interest 		A Financial Conflict of Interest exists when the Recipient’s designated official(s) reasonably determines that an investigator’s significant financial interest could directly and significantly affect the design, conduct, or reporting of the PHS-funded research.  FACA 		Federal Advisory Committee Act

The FACA (FACA) (Pub.L. 92–463, 86 Stat. 770, enacted October 6, 1972), is a United States federal law which governs the behavior of federal Council committees. In particular, it has special emphasis on open meetings, chartering, public involvement, and reporting.

 

https://www.gsa.gov/policy-regulations/policy/federal-Council-committee-act-FACA-management-overview

 

The FACA was enacted in 1972 to ensure that advice by the various Council committees formed over the years is objective and accessible to the public. The Act formalized a process for establishing, operating, overseeing, and terminating these Council bodies and created the Committee Management System Secretariat to monitor compliance with the Act.

In 1976, Executive Order 12024 delegated to the administrator of GSA all responsibilities of the president for implementing the FACA (FACA). Secretariat operations are directed at reporting to the president and Congress on the activities of at least 1000 federal Council committees. Samples of documents and forms used by the Secretariat and its clients can be found in the "Advice and Guidance" pages.

Executive orders and congressional revisions have further refined the extension and the Application of the Act in 1993, 1997, and 1998, and the extent and nature of the Secretariat's reporting of the activities of the committees. The legal history is easy to follow in the "Legislation and Regulation" pages.

 

www.gsa.gov/FACA 

 Technical Assistance Review

An evaluation by NCI Grant management staff to assess an institution's business and financial management systems to ensure that applicable regulations and policies are being followed.

 CCT 		Center for Cancer Training NCI DOC

The CCT (CCT) supports NCI's goal of training cancer researchers for the 21st century. CCT provides funding to support training and career development for cancer researchers working at institutions nationwide and also manages intramural training programs offered at NCI laboratories and offices in Maryland. These cancer training and career development opportunities cover a broad spectrum of disciplines for individuals at career stages ranging from high school and graduate students to scientists, clinicians, and health care professionals.

 

https://www.cancer.gov/Grant-training/training 

 NCAB 		National Cancer Advisory Board Committee

Recommends meritorious Grant Application to IC Director and considers special issues (e.g., appeals of R29 level review)

 

The Council may review Application for Grant and cooperative agreements for research and training and recommend approval of Application for projects which show promise of making valuable contributions to human knowledge; may review any Grant, Contract, or Cooperative Agreement proposed to be made or entered into by the Institute; may collect, by correspondence or by personal investigation, information as to studies which are being carried on in the United States or any other country and, with the approval of the Director of NCI, make available such information through appropriate publications for the benefit of public and private health entities, health professions personnel and scientists, and for the information of the general public; and with the approval of the Executive Secretary, may call upon special consultants, assemble ad hoc working groups, appoint subcommittees and convene workshops and conferences.

 

https://deainfo.NCI.NIH.gov/Council/NCAB/NCAB.htm 

 

Peer Review: NCAB

  • Chartered Council committee consisting of 18 Presidentially- appointed members plus 12 non-voting ex officio members
  • DEA Director is the Executive Secretary of NCAB
  • By legislation, Grant Application must be approved by the NCAB before funding
  • Three meetings per year devoted to extramural CAA
  • Meetings consist of two sessions:
    • “Open” session for NCI Director’s update, special presentations, and subcommittee reports
    • “Closed” session for second level of Peer Review
  • During the Closed Session, the committee
    • Assesses quality of the initial review of Application
    • Makes recommendations on funding and other issues (e.g., foreign institutions, co-funding, etc.)
    • Considers staff recommendations for special actions (e.g., appeal of initial Peer Review)
  • PO is responsible for preparing staff recommendations
  • POs and SRO are encouraged to attend NCAB closed session, as well as pre- and-post NCAB meetings
