 Paylist Manager 		System Research Funding System I2E

Paylist Manager is an I2E Application module that allows OEFIA users to create paylists, which CAA staff then complete and get it approved using the Paylist web Application.

 

Paylist Manager is a module that is used by specific users within the NCI OEFIA (OEFIA) to define and manage fundable Score, DOC exception selection parameters for determining PFR types and enable the creation of paylists per FY and NCAB round.

 

Core Business Functions:

  • Define and Manage Fundable Score for the current FY:
    • Provides the ability to define fundable Score for specific Cost Center/Budget Mechanism/Sub-classification, which may be further broken down by NCI Division/Office/Center and Application Type.
    • Allows users to define separate fundable Score for different RPGs - Standard, New Investigator, Early Stage Investigator, and Large (as needed).
  • Allows users to maintain the DOC Exception Selection parameters for RPGs that is used to determine the Request Type options for Funding Requests in the PFR Application.
  • Create Paylists:
    • Retrieves the applicable Grant Application for a selected FY and Round (aka. NCAB) and creates paylists for each CAA based on the defined fundable Score parameters - Cost Center & Budget Mechanism, NCI Division/Office/Center, Application Type and RPG Type
    • Support the creation of various types of RPG/Traditional Research Grant-R01/RL1 paylists based on the fundable Score and defined rules –Standard, New Investigator, Early Stage Investigator RPG, Large Paylists (as needed).
  • Ability to modify paylists or selected Grant Application on a specific paylists
  • Built-in search capabilities: Once the Paylist is generated, it allows users to view paylists created for a specific FY and Round (aka. NCAB Date).

 

 Primary Users: OEFIA staff (1 to 2 OEFIA staff are responsible to manage the fundable Score and create paylists for each NCAB round in a given FY)

 SRO 		Scientific Review Officer, Scientific Review Administrator Role

The NIH official who serves as the designated Federal official having legal responsibility for managing the Peer Review meeting, the procedures for evaluating the Application assigned to the SRG and the determinations and management of conflicts of interest, as noted in 42 CFR 52(h).

 

A Federal scientist who presides over a SRG (SRG) and is responsible for coordinating and

reporting the review of each Application assigned to his/her committee, thereby serving as an intermediary between the Applicant institution and the reviewers of the Application. The SRO prepares a Summary Statement for each Application reviewed by his/her SRG.

 

Role description:

 

Pre Peer Review Meeting:

  • Application assigned to SRGs based on FOA and/or science proposed
  • Once Application are referred for review, SRO becomes the point of contact for all review-related issues
  • PO checks Application for responsiveness and may suggest potential reviewers to SRO
  • SRO performs administrative review and scientific needs assessment in preparation for reviewer recruitment

 

SRO is responsible for:

  • Assembling review panel
  • Managing conflicts of interest
  • Making reviewer assignments
  • Providing reviewers with access to Application and review materials
  • Orienting reviewers prior to meeting

 

 Summary Statement

Within four weeks of the Peer Review committee meeting, the Summary Statement will be available on the eRA Commons. The SRA prepares the Summary Statement which contains:

  • Overall resume and summary of review discussion (if scored);
  • Critiques by the reviewers;
  • Priority Score and percentile ranking ( if scored; also not all Application receive a percentile ranking);
  • Budget recommendations; and
  • Administrative notes.

The Summary Statement becomes the official Institute or Center record of the recommendations made by the Peer Review committee. Once the Summary Statement is available, you can contact your PO (listed on the Summary Statement) if you have specific questions.

It also includes programs where access to a specific NIH research resource is needed to conduct certain research.

 SPL 		NCI Scientific Program Leadership Committee, Scientific Program Leadership Committee, NCI Executive Committee, EC Committee

Around October 1st, the beginning of a new federal FY, the SPL (SPL) discusses CAA priorities and preliminary funding allocations. In order to determine the CAA allocations, the SPL considers:

  • Congressional mandates
  • New scientific opportunities
  • New initiatives
  • CAA priorities
  • Previous commitments, such as noncompeting continuations
  • Other projected needs
  • Anticipated availability of funds

The SPL cannot make final allocations and funding decisions until they know the actual amount of the federal Appropriation.

 

 

SPL == SPL ???

 

The SPL (SPL), which consists of high-level Institute managers, makes all major organizational and operating decisions affecting the NCI, including:

  • Formulating scientific and management policy decisions
  • Establishing funding plans for Grant programs not administered solely by one Division
  • Approving certain exceptions to Grant funding plans
  • Reviewing Contract, Cooperative Agreement and Grant concepts
  • Formulating the long-range strategic plan for the Institute
  • Addressing trans-NCI policy issues affecting personnel and resources

 

 FAM 		Financial Analysis Manager Role

The FAM system is used (by OEFIA) to perform the budgetary exercises necessary to execute the extramural Budget. PFR and GPMATS are two I2E modules with data that also update FAM.

 

FAM maintains up-to-date estimates of NCI Award disbursals and planned future spending.

 R34 		NIH Clinical Trial Planning Grant (R34) Program, NIH Clinical Trial Planning Grant

R34

  • Designed to permit early Peer Review of the rationale for the proposed clinical trial and support development of essential elements of a clinical trial
  • Usually Project Period of one year, sometimes up to 3
  • Usually, allows for a Budget of up to $100,000 Direct Costs, sometimes up to $450,000
  • Used only by select ICs; no parent FOA

 

 https://Grant.NIH.gov/Grant/funding/R34.htm

 NGRI 		Next Generation Research Initiative
 IRG 		Initial Review Group, Integrated Review Group Committee

Disambiguation:

IRG (IRG): Cluster of SRGs with related scientific focus; serves as locus of initial Assignment of Application (CSR only).

versus

NCI IRG: Composed of FACA-chartered subcommittees; review of training and career development Application, and final Score for Cancer Center Support Grant Application (NCI only)

 

Initial review of NIH Grant Application is handled by the "Initial Review Groups" comprising both CSR (CSR) study sections and review committees of the individual NIH institutes.

Review activities of the CSR (CSR) are organized into Integrated Review Groups (IRG). Each IRG represents a cluster of study sections in a general scientific R15. Application generally are assigned R29 to an IRG, and then to a specific SRG within that IRG for evaluation of scientific merit.

 

https://public.CSR.NIH.gov/studysections/integratedreviewgroups/Pages/default.aspx 

 RMS 		Research Management and Support, NCI Research Management and Support

NCI RMS activities provide support for the review, Award, and Monitoring of technical and administrative services. These services include central administration, overall CAA direction, Grant and Contract administration, human resources, CAA coordination, and financial management. NCI regularly engages in business planning activities to streamline administrative functions.

 

The RMS (RMS) Budget includes the scientific and administrative management expenses associated with the Institute’s day-to-day operations. It also reflects the costs associated with the review of Application for Grant and contracts by special panels of outside experts and the management and evaluation of Grant and contracts after they are awarded. Expenses incurred to disseminate research results and health information to patients, health care providers, and the American public are included as well.

 IAR 		Internet Assisted Review System eRA Research Funding System

IAR is an eRA Application module: A system outside of Peer Review which allows reviewers to submit critiques and preliminary scores for Application they are reviewing and allows Reviewers, SRO, and ESA to view all critiques in preparation for a meeting. IAR creates a preliminary Summary Statement body containing submitted critiques for the SRO or ESA.

 LOI 		Letter of Intent

Many Funding Opportunity Announcements (FOA) (whether CAA Announcements or Requests for Application) request that prospective applicants submit a LOI prior to the submission of a Application. For those FOA that request it, a LOI should include the following:

  • Descriptive title of proposed research
  • Name, address, and telephone number of the PI(s)
  • Names of other Key Personnel
  • Participating institutions
  • Number and title of the funding opportunity

 

Although a LOI is not required, is not binding, and does not enter into the review of a subsequent Application, the information that it contains allows IC (IC) staff to estimate the potential review workload and plan the review.

The LOI should be sent by the date listed on the specific FOA and to the contact and address listed therein. For more information, contact the PO (Scientific/Research Contact(s)) listed in the FOA.

Also, remember that if your Budget is at or going to exceed $500,000 in Direct Costs for any year of the project, NIH policy (NOT-OD-02-004) requires Prior Approval from IC programmatic staff at least six weeks prior to the anticipated submission date. Information regarding this approval should be submitted in a cover letter along with the Application.
